question: 掛ける
sourceAnswer: to{}{hang-up-(e.g.-a-coat,-a-picture-on-the-wall)/let-hang/suspend-(from)/hoist-(e.g.-sail)/raise-(e.g.-flag)} | to{}{put-on-(e.g.-a-blanket)/put-on-top-of/cover/lay/spread} | to{}{put-on-(glasses,-etc.)/wear-(a-necklace,-etc.)} | to{}make-(a-call) | to{}{spend-(time,-money)/expend/use} | to{}{pour-(liquid)-onto/sprinkle-(powder-or-spices)-onto/splash/throw-(e.g.-water)-onto} | to{}{turn-on-(engine,-radio,-etc.)/set-(dial,-alarm-clock,-etc.)/put-on-(DVD,-song,-etc.)/use-(device,-implement,-etc.)} | to{}{cause-(somebody-inconvenience,-trouble,-etc.)/burden-(someone)/impose} | to{}multiply-(arithmetic-operation) | to{}secure-(e.g.-lock) | to{}{take-a-seat/sit/rest-(something-on-something-else)/support-(something-on-something-else)} | to{}bind | to{}{wager/bet/risk/stake/gamble} | to{}put-an-effect-(spell,-anaesthetic,-etc.)-on | to{}hold-(a-play,-festival,-etc.) | to{}hold-an-emotion-for-(pity,-hope,-etc.) | to{}{argue-(in-court)/deliberate-(in-a-meeting)/present-(e.g.-idea-to-a-conference,-etc.)} | to{}increase-further | to{}catch-(in-a-trap,-etc.) | to{}set-atop | to{}erect-(a-makeshift-building) | to{}apply-(insurance) | to{}{pun-(on-a-word)/use-(a-word)-as-a-pivot-word/play-on-words} | to{?}{be-partway-doing-.../begin-(but-not-complete)-.../be-about-to-...} | to{?}{address-(someone)/direct-(something,-to-someone)/do-(something,-to-someone)}
userAnswer: to{} put-on/hang/hook | apply/initiate/do/cause/launch | make | turn-on | use | wager
activeAnswer: to{} put-on/hang/hook | apply/initiate/do/cause/launch | make | turn-on | use | wager
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hang</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hang something</vocabulary>. This is when you hang something, like a picture. You can remember this because you don't really <reading>care</reading> (<ja>ける</ja>) about where you hang it, as long as you're the one to do it.
sourceReadingMnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.
references: Cure Dolly: かける / かかる
